transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Really just our story and how we have developed
LoadStar over the past three years.
So about us, my name is Kamin.
I work at ChainSafe.
It is a great company.
We're hiring.
We basically build blockchains.
We have a whole bunch of layer one projects.
LoadStar is one of them.
But if you are interested in getting into core development,
we're a really great place, great culture.
So LoadStar is one of these projects at ChainSafe.
We're basically an ETH2 or Ethereum consensus ecosystem
written entirely in TypeScript.
We really take the open source ethos to heart.
We have all of our meetings.
They're public.
Everything we do is public.
And we really encourage anyone who wants to contribute.
We try to help people out and get people involved.
A lot of our team members actually started their work
on the project through their open source contributions.
And it was kind of like an open source
to contract to hire a kind of a situation.
So we really like that kind of ethos.
What we're talking about today is specifically
our consensus client and how we got from prototyping
prototypical kind of code to something
that's like production ready, something
that you can really rely on, something that doesn't just
blow up all the time.
So before I kind of step into our story,
I just want to kind of do a very high level of what metrics
are.
I'm not going to go too deep if you really
want to go no more.
You can read the docs about these things.
So metrics, in our case, we're using Prometheus.
Prometheus basically gives you the tools
to build time series data for specific elements
that you want to track in your code.
The kind of three main things that you're tracking,
is your counter, a gauge, or a histogram.
We'll go into some examples of all of these things.
But basically what you want to know about metrics
are you have some value, something in your code
that you're wanting to track.
And Prometheus will kind of query your software over time.
And you can get a sense over time of how things are changing,
how things are moving.
Then you use Grafana to visualize these metrics.
So a picture is like 1,000 words.
So it's basically the difference between looking
at a bunch of logs and then looking at pretty graphs
that can show you--
give you a little more insight, give you
something at a higher level than just squinting.
So our story.
Basically, we started with really bad--
with not very much infrastructure,
not very much a discipline in how we tackled metrics or tackled
the data that we track.
And eventually, we kind of--
over time and through a lot of pain and suffering,
we kind of realized that metrics are the way to go.
Metrics give you insights that you'll never
get just by looking at logs.
So really metrics aggregate a bunch of information
and give you the tools you need to make better decisions
about how you release your product, what things to focus on,
like what are priorities.
And they're also just really pretty.
So they're cool.
So this is a picture from the early days of LoadStar,
from the Interop Lock-In in Musco-Good 2019.
Here's our message.
Yeah, we're stuck syncing in some P2P issues.
We didn't really know what was going on,
like why things are breaking.
We were looking at logs actually on the other side
of the screen here.
We look happy, but it's like, oh, things are breaking.
Here's some funny issues that we had.
You can see priority low adding Prometheus monitoring.
We didn't even know we were doing--
yeah, out of memory, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh,
oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh,
oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh, oh,
throughout 2019 into 2020, LoadStar was very prototype,
very much like a prototype.
And we ran into the issues time and time again.
Like, we would have the same thing happen multiple times,
and we weren't like regressions that were happening,
and we weren't really like learning our lesson.
Kind of the turning point was starting to take some time
to really take the time to build out these metrics
and build out these dashboards.
So we had a contributor.
I think I can save a new world, maybe with peace.
And so throughout 2021, we started going really hardcore
into adding a bunch of metrics and taking time
to think through what questions that we want to answer,
what pieces of code are dark, where is--
where are we spending time in our software,
where is a bunch of memory being spent,
really uncovering all of the complexity
of this running software.
Blockchains are really complicated software.
There's a whole bunch going on.
And unless you're really tracking key pieces,
you're kind of going blind.
And now we're finally kind of at a point
where for any new feature that we're adding,
we ask for metrics.
So it'd be very important to track the retry behavior,
meaning add metrics for.
So that brings me to metrics-driven development.
Really, the kind of the key thing that we've learned
is that every large feature should
be documented with metrics.
So if you are adding a case of a retry mechanism,
you're adding some new feature, you
need to make sure that it's actually working.
And the only way that you can--
or we're not the only way, but the really great way
of doing that is being able to show that visually.
Being able to show, OK, our cache is now bounded.
Let's see that in the metrics.
Let's see how that cache is growing over time.
Or let's see how many times the retry mechanism is actually
being activated.
Those are the sorts of things that you really only
can find through these graphical methods,
through these metrics.
You're going to have a really hard time looking
at the logs for that.
The other thing about metrics-driven development
is that any deployed software that you use,
you need to be monitoring it very carefully for regressions.
So you look here, this is the process heap increasing over time.
And this is a comment from Lyon.
For the last two days, the leak is clearly visible,
an impact of 75 megabytes a day.
Yeah, so that's going to be a problem.
If your blockchain is--
if it's just increasing at 75 megabytes a day,
continuously, you're going to run on a memory.
And we were able to catch this issue before we actually
cut a release.
So it makes your release process a lot better.
Here's another example of a regression.
We deployed a version of our software.
We saw the cache size grow.
It's like, oh, is that a bug?
Is it OK?
Well, we only actually caught it because we're
tracking these things.
You probably aren't even going to have a log that's
going to show you your cache sizes.
So unless you actually measure this, you're going to be blind.
The other great thing about dashboards and about metrics
is that it lets you correlate different pieces of the code
to find out where the problem is.
So here we have different-- you can
see a bunch of different graphs all at the same time
and see, OK, something is affecting the event loop lag.
I can see at the same time, the active number of handles
is growing.
The number of requests is growing.
So you can kind of solve the mystery in a way
that you're not going to be able to do in the logs.
Another great strategy is using different versions
if you're running software.
So running a staging version of your software
against a production version or against several recent versions
and being able to overlay data on top of one another
and being able to see, OK, well, it looks like our beta version
is using a whole bunch more memory than our unstable version.
So being able to compare and contrast,
it gives you the tools to do this.
And so just kind of like drilling down to a few tips,
these are very, very practical kind of tips.
Don't abuse the histograms.
So I said there's three different types of metrics.
You just want to now use the simplest tool possible.
Histograms are really only used if you're
wanting to see the kind of the distribution of something.
So maybe looking at request timing,
maybe you'll want to see certain requests are happening very,
very quickly, but then others are happening kind of longer.
So a classic mistake with histograms
is using a label that's unbounded.
So if you had a metric that was tracking something
per peer ID on the network, well, you might have thousands
of peers.
And if each new peer is going to be using a new peer ID,
it's going to blow the metrics up
and it's going to affect the performance of Prometheus.
And you're not going to be able to run the queries
that you want to run.
Oh, so how do you know which metrics to add?
So I showed some of these pretty graphs and everything.
But in your software, how do you know what you want to track?
So really what you want to do is think about questions
that you couldn't ask otherwise.
So a really good example is the size of your internal caches.
Another thing you can think about is
like if this feature or if this part of the code
would degrade or explode in the kind of bad case,
that's a prime candidate for adding metrics around it.
And then really just keep asking questions.
And then it's like if you have the data
to be able to answer the question, you're good.
But otherwise keep adding metrics until you can answer
those questions.
So some examples that we've kind of come across.
How often are our streams being reset?
How many peers do we have?
These are the kinds of questions that the metrics can help.
And so I'm going to show you just a live demo
or a live example of our dashboards
and we can kind of run through some things.
And if anyone has any questions about it,
while I'm going through it, we can do that too.
OK, so this is our dashboard for our fleet
of beacon nodes and validators.
This is kind of the high level dashboard.
Right now we're looking at an unstable node.
But we can go to a stable version of LoadStar.
So this is running version 1.1 or on the girly network.
We're synced.
It looks like it got restarted about a day ago.
Some interesting things.
I guess peer count is looking good.
All right, there's nothing-- everything looks stable there.
And we track different types of peers inbound, outbound.
And for us, we really care about the number of peers
that we're going to be receiving messages from kind
of continuously.
Those are our gossip peers.
So the number of mesh peers on our core topics,
staying about six or seven.
It looks like we're connected to a lot of lighthouse nodes
and a lot of prism nodes.
And there's another LoadStar out there.
Let's drill into something a little more detailed here.
So one area that we really struggled with,
and where we added a lot of metrics,
is in our gossip sub-implementation.
We found through adding a few metrics
that we weren't getting blocks on time.
And it turned out that we didn't have enough peers who
were sending us blocks.
And then we started asking questions.
All right, well, why are they not sending us blocks?
It turned out it was because our peer scoring was too low.
Well, why was the score too low?
Well, it turned out it was because there
was a specific part of the scoring that was too low.
And so we kind of-- you can start asking questions,
and you can build up--
you start building the answers to that.
OK, so what you're seeing here is some of what
I was talking about.
We have breaking out the score into different components
that different parameters that are going into your kind
of aggregated score for peers.
What we were seeing before is you'd
see a graph where the values are going down and down
and down over time, or if they're
very negative numbers.
Another really useful metric that we check a lot is things
related to the VM.
So memory, CPU, and disk storage.
So it looks like our memory is stable.
That's great.
GC is only taking roughly 7 and 1/2%.
This is-- things are looking good.
[VIDEO PLAYBACK]
Yeah, I think that's enough of a demo here.
So at this point, open to questions,
and we're also hiring.
So if any of this looks cool or interesting,
and you know, type scripts?
- Hello, and thank you for the talk.
So I see that you have a ton of metrics.
And I believe that most of them are useful.
But do you have some kind of an alerting system for you
to be able to know when a metric has gone wrong?
Because I think it's just unfeasible
to go through each of them like daily or something like that.
I think you need some automated way to alert you
that something is going wrong.
- Yeah, absolutely.
So that was something I didn't touch on,
but it definitely feeds in.
So we use pager duty.
You can basically set up thresholds
for certain metrics that trigger either slack notifications
or discord notifications, or in the case of a critical kind
of issue, it'll call you or text you.
Yeah, we do have that set up.
I would definitely recommend that if you are running something
in production.
- Thank you.
Again, there are lots of metrics.
Did you guys develop over time a way to,
or kind of a mental model or framework
to decide how to or to put them whenever you have new graph
or metric instead of, or do you just like decide
to put it somewhere and then go back and make,
to make it easy to read or to browse the dashboard?
I don't know if that makes sense.
- There's a question about organizing the--
- Yeah, exactly.
- Yeah, so I think probably I have to grow it organically.
So what we did is we started with one dashboard
that grew and grew and grew and eventually it became kind
of unsustainable to have everything just piled together.
So we started breaking it apart.
The other thing that, the other kind of issue
that we had initially is we would create a bunch of metrics
but we wouldn't add them to the dashboard.
So there was no actual like visual cue for a lot of it.
And so it kind of just went unnoticed.
And so one thing we would definitely recommend
would be like if you add a metric,
also add it to the dashboard at the same time.
- Thank you.
The question about storage.
So again, too much metrics, primitios or what?
- Does it affect the storage?
Well, so some of it depends on your architecture
of how you're deploying this.
So what we do is we actually have one Prometheus
and Grafana server servicing all our entire fleet
of beacon nodes.
So we have a bunch of different machines
and then we have one machine for these right to do things.
So it doesn't cut into the storage.
We retain for a month.
- Quick question.
Are the metrics relevant for like other EVM chains
besides Ethereum mainnet?
Or is it just like specific to Ethereum mainnet?
- Yeah, a good question.
So I'd say like, I don't know if it's a half and half,
but like half of the metrics are like more like
for like monitoring the chain,
something like a block explorer kind of thing.
But I would say like a lot of the metrics
are specific to the implementation.
So, and those are the ones that are, I think,
probably more helpful.
Just the internal caches and like timing,
timings of things that were really, really wanting to get right.

And if so, would you maybe consider like,

so like anybody can see them and apply that

- Right, I know that other clients do have metrics

those are the ones that look more like a block explorer
and maybe with some like validator,
like showing your balance ticking up over time.
And I think those are public and I,
and there is an effort to standardize metrics
across the consensus clients.
So I think some of that's happening.
But again, to the previous question,
a lot of the metrics will always be implementation specific.
- In terms of roles and team members
who generally looks at which metrics and which graphs
just kind of to get an idea of,
which metrics and graphs are useful to which team members
or depending on like the role or the type of work that they do.
- You're asking if only certain members contribute to these?
- More like the looking at the graphs
and the browsing the metrics themselves.
Like, you know, for example, there are lots of metrics,
so not everybody looks at everything.
So you know, it's more what team members look at,
look at what kinds of graphs are.
- Right, so for any of these larger feature pull requests,
we have the person who is authoring or kind of owning
that feature, they're responsible for making the case
that it's correct and then it works as intended.
And so they're responsible for looking at the metrics
and building that case.
And then as far as like our release process,
we have a checklist of basic things that we look at
before we actually release.
We have a testing period, so we cut a beta release,
we deploy it to our fleet, and we watch it for a few days,
and then after a few days, we gather, you know,
do the checklist and any other kind of ad hoc things
that we're noticing then.

like you can have one Prometheus and Grafana running,
